comments:
Management 784 develops students' abilities to apply game theory to decision-making. Game theory has become an important tool for managers and consultants in analyzing and implementing tactical as well as strategic actions. This course will primarily focus on examples useful for developing competitive strategy in the private sector. Game theory can also be used to address problems relevant to a firm’s organizational strategy and to a firm’s non-market environment. 

While many students considered the material “really interesting,” they felt that it was not delivered well. Furthermore, the material was criticized as too theoretical, with “little discussion of where the theory breaks down in the real world.” The course consists of problem sets, case discussion and an exam. 

Students felt that Professor Thomas did not present the material in an organized way. While Professor Thomas is knowledgeable about his field, students wished that he had been more enthusiastic, engaged and responsive. Students often did not receive responses to e-mails and had difficulty meeting with him during office hours. 

This course is a required substitute for MGEC 621. Students who had taken game theory courses in college, did not feel that this course taught them anything new. Most students felt that the material presented in this course has potential for a fun and interesting course but that this potential has yet to be met.
